20110121200644.000|20110121200647.000|TR0|want to call it that, because the -- the

20110121200649.000|20110121200652.000|TR0|exited in the -- in what they call the 
20110121200652.000|20110121200654.000|TR0|left hemisphere of the brain, and it 
20110121200654.000|20110121200657.000|TR0|didn't cross the hemisphere.  So -- so 
20110121200657.000|20110121200700.000|TR0|that could be why she's doing as well as

20110121200702.000|20110121200705.000|TR0|
20110121200705.000|20110121200707.000|TR0|COHEN:  Right.
20110121200707.000|20110121200710.000|TR0|
20110121200710.000|20110121200713.000|TR0|The fact that the bullet did not cross 
20110121200713.000|20110121200715.000|TR0|that midsection, that it entered and left 
20110121200715.000|20110121200718.000|TR0|in the same hemisphere, on the same side 
20110121200718.000|20110121200721.000|TR0|is really, really crucial, because, once a 
20110121200721.000|20110121200723.000|TR0|bullet or fragments of bullets cross to 
20110121200723.000|20110121200726.000|TR0|the other side, then you have disturbed 
20110121200726.000|20110121200728.000|TR0|many more structures of the brain, speech 
20110121200728.000|20110121200731.000|TR0|centers and emotional centers and other 
20110121200731.000|20110121200734.000|TR0|parts of the brain that are really quite
